Award.AwardTitle: Neuroendocrine modulation of sleep under starvation stress in Drosophila
Award.AbstractNarration:
Sleep and feeding are both indispensable for life and are strictly controlled for their own need. However, these essential behaviors are mutually exclusive, and therefore their regulatory processes significantly influence one another. Sleep loss leads to stimulation of appetite, and food deprivation leads to a suppression of sleep. Elucidation of the basic mechanisms underlying these interactions between sleep and feeding is highly significance, as it is expected to provide insights into fundamental principles by which animals efficiently adapt their behaviors in response to changes in external environments and internal states. The focus of the study is on steroid hormones and their involvement in starvation-induced sleep suppression (SISS), an evolutionarily conserved behavioral response to starvation. The outcome of this research is expected to make an important general contribution to the field of behavioral neuroendocrinology, given the universal importance of the molecular components studied (steroids, dopamine and G-protein coupled receptor), and the adaptive behavior of interest (SISS). The project will also provide unique training opportunities for undergraduate, with an emphasis on broadening participation through involvement of underrepresented minorities, as well as graduate students and promote outreach activities targeting local students and general public.

This project uses the fruit fly, Drosophila melanogaster as a model system and investigates how the endocrine system regulates the nervous system to control sleep and feeding. The research will elucidate how the G-protein coupled receptor DopEcR interacts with neuromodulators to control sleep under the stress associated with starvation. The central hypothesis is that dopamine acts on DopEcR in the context of starvation, counteracting the effects of ecdysone on DopEcR by reducing the strength of epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) signaling, and that this in turn induces SISS. This hypothesis will be tested through two specific aims: 1) Identify the critical sites of DopEcR action in regulating SISS, and 2) Determine the roles of ecdysone, dopamine and EGFR signaling in DopEcR-mediated SISS. Preliminary studies in the PI's group have revealed that Drosophila DopEcR, a unique G-protein coupled receptor (GPCR) that responds to both the major insect steroid hormone ecdysone and the catecholamine dopamine plays a critical role in SISS. The study will identify the critical anatomical sites of DopEcR action in regulating SISS, and determining the roles and mechanisms of ecdysone and dopamine in DopEcR-mediated SISS.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The long-term goal of our research is to understand how gene-environment interactions modulate behaviors by affecting the nervous and endocrine systems. Steroid hormones function as neuromodulators and play important roles in behavioral regulation in response to environmental changes. We are interested in the roles and action mechanisms of steroid hormones in regulation of sleep under stressful conditions, in particular, starvation stress. Sleep and feeding are both essential for survival, and each behavior is homeostatically regulated for its own needs. However, because animals are not able to sleep and eat simultaneously, regulatory mechanisms of these behaviors must interact functionally. Using the fruit fly Drosophila melanogaster, we have found that Dopamine/Ecdysteroid receptor (DopEcR), a unique receptor for the main insect steroid hormone ecdysone and the catecholamine dopamine, plays a critical role in sleep suppression under starvation. The biological actions of steroid hormones are mediated primarily by “genomic” mechanisms, with steroids binding directly to nuclear hormone receptors that serve as transcription factors. DopEcR is unique in that it is a membrane-bound G-protein coupled receptor responsible for unconventional “non-genomic” steroid signaling. Our study has demonstrated that DopEcR is essential for sleep suppression under starvation. We have further shown that knocking down epidermal growth factor (EGF) receptor signaling rescues defects of DopEcR loss-of-function mutants in starvation-induced sleep suppression. These results indicate that in wild type animals, starvation induces sleep suppression by down-regulating EGF receptor signaling in a DopEcR-dependent manner. Since starvation-induced sleep suppression is an evolutionarily conserved behavioral response to food deprivation, it is possible that other animals use the similar mechanisms to modulate sleep under starvation stress.

 

To obtain an independent insight into the mechanisms by which DopEcR modulates sleep behavior in response to starvation stress, we sought to understand the physiological function of DopEcR in the brain. For this purpose, we employed a novel Ca2+-imaging approach with a bioluminescent reporter. This approach uses a GFP-Aequorin fusion construct that binds to Ca2+ and emits light, eliminating the need for light excitation. This method has an advantage over conventional because it permits long continuous imaging, access to deep brain structures and high temporal resolution. Using this approach, we investigated the functional significance of DopEcR for controlling neuronal activity in the mushroom bodies (MBs), an important brain region that integrates information about internal and external environments and sends outputs to control behaviors. We have found that reduction of DopEcR activity in the MBs enhances the excitability of the MB medial lobes, while ecdysone signaling through DopEcR modulates the excitability of the MB calyx and cell bodies. Although these results do not directly explain how DopEcR regulates sleep under starvation conditions, they have laid the scientific foundation for the future analysis of DopEcR function at the cellular, circuit, and behavioral levels.

 

 

In the course of characterizing DopEcR mutant phenotypes, we have found that they display abnormal responses to not only starvation but also various other stresses, including ethanol exposure, social stress, and heat. Since unconventional “non-genomic” steroid signaling still remains unexplored particularly in the context of stress response, we will continue studying Drosophila DopEcR to better understand how environmental factors interact with the nervous and endocrine systems and ultimately regulate animal behaviors.

 

 

This project has made a significant contribution to science education. In total, two graduate and seven undergraduate students participated in this project. One of the graduate students successfully obtained her PhD for the study of this project. The other graduate student is still in his 3rd year and a chapter of his thesis is expected to be devoted to this project. The findings made in this project were presented at local, national, and international science meetings, and have so far culminated in two publications in peer-review journals.
